Reviews.Content: Games are very slow or don't work at all. I can't download adobe flash or google play cause it comes up with an error..or any other app that makes games play faster. Pretty disappointed

Reviews.Title: great performance
Reviews.Author: María Sol Pérez Aguirreburualde
Reviews.Content: As far as now, has reached all my espectations.I have used it for skype chats with my family in europe and has work even better than my lapton, in concern about image and sound.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic!
Reviews.Author: Robert F.
Reviews.Content: As always, Samsung delivers a top quality device that pays for itself. The display is beautiful and holds its charge for hours. Only problem i think was that i think it could have came with a 64gb micro sd card, (instead of seperately sold). My qife and i have enjoyed and are glad we bought this over an ipad.

Reviews.Title: Awful battery life
Reviews.Author: Michelle Carter
Reviews.Content: For the most part the tablet works fine but the battery runs out quickly.  I had the tablet turned on for 11 minutes and it is at 89% already.  The battery is supposed to last 12 hours when fully charged, but that is not the case.I have yet to find a simple method to sync files between the tablet and my computers and that is a big drawback.

Reviews.Title: Really worth your while
Reviews.Author: L. Crumbie "LC"
Reviews.Content: Excellent substitute for a textbook. Love the resolution, the free extra 50GB on dropbox and the battery life is pretty decent.

Reviews.Title: Does not replace laptop functions
Reviews.Author: Minapinkie
Reviews.Content: The memory runs out quickly and it lacks many things that I'm used to in a laptop like the Microsoft office programs and you can't connect it to the TV using the standard hdmi cords. I thought this world replace my laptop but I only ended up using it to watch Netflix check my email and surf the web.

Reviews.Title: great tablet
Reviews.Author: MikeyT
Reviews.Content: i bought this tablet because of ite reviews, size, weight and overall connectivity. it will be used in remote locations instead on packing up a laptop and dragging it along everywhere. with a myfi unit it can be used anywhere.

Reviews.Title: Great Purchase!
Reviews.Author: Jocelyn Duryea
Reviews.Content: I love it! First time tablet owner - it is sleek, easy to use, amazing screen - no complaints at all!

Reviews.Title: Holds charge just like your smart phone
Reviews.Author: Picky consumer. "F"
Reviews.Content: Sure, it does not have draconian restrictions that Apple has, but its battery performance is mediocre at best. Even when not being used, it lasts 2-3 days. With regular use I have to charge it every night.

Reviews.Title: lovin it
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "Island Reader"
Reviews.Content: My first tablet and I love it. Steep learning curve though. Hard to get used to typing with one finger.  I just found the cursor after working on it for 4 hrs..which seems 2 be the life of 1 battery charge. I am sorry that it took Amazon 18 days 2 get it 2 me. I should NOT have picked free shipping!  It was also packed in a 2nd box with an airbag that was ripped and no air in it so it did slide around in the larger box. Fortunately, it seems 2 have survived shipment by fedexpost!

Reviews.Title: does everything I need it to - with ease
Reviews.Author: Miriam Yiannakis
Reviews.Content: This is my second Samsung Galaxy Tab (toddler son smashed my previous one).  Love the changes for the new tab. perfect for my work, and play.  does everything I need it to.The only down side is that when I have it in it's stand, I can't plug it into a power source to charge because the plug-in spot is on the bottom edge when I use it in landscape view (which is how it fits in my stand/keyboard case).  still love it though.

Reviews.Title: I am happy with it.
Reviews.Author: Bob Montgomery
Reviews.Content: There may be faster,  bigger,  better tablets out there but I am very happy with mine.  I also have an Asus but like this one better so far.  It simply does what a good tablet should do.  I recommend it. 12/27/13. I just found out Amazon Prime won't let you stream video to this device.

Reviews.Title: Great gift !!
Reviews.Author: Mark wilbanks
Reviews.Content: I have an Apple Ipad 2 and I love it but I just got my husband the Samsung Galaxy and I was ultimately pleasantly surprised to see that a lot of it was exactly like my IPad although some things were actually better . Like the first initial setup is really easy , the home screen and what to do and navigating on it was so much simpler than any tablet I've ever seen . Wow Wow Wow sound is awsome and graphics are nice . The picture when we compare mine to his while watching a Netflix movie his picture on the Galaxy looked substantially better :) Would recommend this tablet to anyone looking for a nice one to own !

Reviews.Title: Great tablet for everyday use!
Reviews.Author: Catherine Jensen
Reviews.Content: I have had this tablet for over a month now, and am very happy with it!  I have a Samsung Galaxy Nexus phone, so the sync capability obviously is a key part of the experience.  I am an Android user and wanted a tablet with an Intel processor, so this tablet was perfect for me.  I am not a very 'techy' person, so i actually let this sit in it's box for over a month before i decided to go through the typical painful set-up process.  However, this tablet was VERY quick and easy to set-up and sync to my Google accounts, etc.  I didn't even have to ask my husband to help, as normally when I get a new phone, i give it to him to set up for me.  The tablet interface is easy to use, my only complaint is I can't minimize or shrink windows so to have multiple windows side-by-side.  Or if there is a way to do this, i haven't figured it out yet.  But you can obviously have multiple aps running at the same time, and easy to move between them.  It's nice to have the larger screen to do all the normal multi-tasking I would use my phone for.  Example is last week I was sitting on my couch, watching Thurs night football, using the tablet to monitor my fantasy football team, was also doing online Christmas shopping, managing Sonos (playing in the background), catching up w/ Words with Friends, and an occasional game of the Jewel Blitz game (addictive!).  This tablet has a good-sized screen, light-weight, runs fast, and battary lasts a decent period of time.  For the price, a great tablet!  highly recommend!

Reviews.Title: Excellent Product
Reviews.Author: Philip Loria
Reviews.Content: My wife has an I-Pad but I just don't like Apple products. Being very Happy with my Samsung Galaxy III phone I decided to get this unit. Setup was easy and it's quite easy to use. I am quite pleased. Great screen resolution and easy to read / see.It is a bit slow to recharge.

Reviews.Title: EXCELLENT
Reviews.Author: stepsocal
Reviews.Content: Great, product! It is very user friendly. Would recommend to anybody who is not an expert in these new gadgets. It is very easy to use

Reviews.Title: Awesome
Reviews.Author: Migie Lee-Saulas
Reviews.Content: The product arived on time.. great spead and apps.. loving it to the max. the children are delighted to play games on it and the battery life is in excess of 8 hours while playing games. Awesome

Reviews.Title: Awesome
Reviews.Author: Ken Moss
Reviews.Content: everything they said it would be and more. I had the BlackBerry Play Book and its nothing like this Samsung Galaxy tablet. the versatility, flexibility.

Reviews.Title: I did I get along without one????
Reviews.Author: Conitis
Reviews.Content: I really enjoy my Samsung tablet.  Its great for traveling with free wi-fi in most hotels and motels.  It's easier viewing streaming video than on my home computer.

Reviews.Title: Smooth as air
Reviews.Author: Agustin Houlgrave
Reviews.Content: This is a masterpiece from the Samsung people. You'll just love your Samsung galaxy Tab 3. Excellent! I totally recommend it!

Reviews.Title: Samsung Galaxy Tab 3
Reviews.Author: Lisa Cupid
Reviews.Content: It's light weight and easy to use - a great addition to the Samsung family of phone, laptop and now tablet!

Reviews.Title: NOT THE BEST CHOICE FOR KINDLE BOOKS, OR KIDS
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "Bullone"
Reviews.Content: I would like to give this unit the five star rating that I give my 7 inch Tab 2,  but I can't.  The buttons shown on the bottom get in the way when used in the portrait position.  Kindle books are best read in that position,  so you have to be very careful where you hold the device along the edges, or you will be back to the apps screen.  Also the edges are too pressure sensitive causing strange things to happen,  just when you don't want them to.  Now if you buy a tablet cover case,  you may be able to avoid some of these problems, depending on the case.  Sitting  upright in the landscape position (in tablet cover) with a stylus being used,  this unit works remarkably well.  But if you want to lie on the counch and read a Kindle book,  I would choose another unit.  I know I will prefer my 7 inch Tab 2 for that purpose.As for kids, I have several grandkids who couldn't wait to get their hands on the unit.  But they keep hitting the back and home keys.  I wouldn't recommend this tablet for kids either

Reviews.Title: Comparison between Tab3 and iPad2
Reviews.Author: NJmom
Reviews.Content: Our family bought an ipad2 almost 2 years ago and since every one wants to use it I am getting tired of it.  So over the Thanksgiving weekend we bought this (with the $100 off from Costco) as it was on sale.  So far here are the differences we noticed:1) The ipad2 is more responsive when it comes to selecting things.  I shop alot at Kohls and it was horrible how I can't get anything sorted because I can't get it to register my touch.2) We can actually use this as a GPS (we tried it out, he ipad we have has only WIFI).  This is a plus because our GPS just broke and we were thinking of replacing it (and now we don't).3) I miss facetime (but supposedly there is other substitute for it which we have not tried).4) I use the ipad before with the abc app to sometimes catch up with shows I miss.  The abc app on this is lousy (it would stop working in the middle of it) and the quality of the picture is not so good.5) we don't think this supports the international keyboard (we really like to get the kids to practice writing Chinese words on the ipad which they don't really do but the functionality is there)6) there are apps that supposedly support microsoft documents like powerpoint and words.7) Both don't have flash player supportSo currently I'm using this to play games and check mails and web browsing.  I would have liked it much better if I can watch shows but right now I have to steal the family ipad or use a laptop instead for that.

Reviews.Title: it's great
Reviews.Author: Nadia Nunez
Reviews.Content: Love it! Just wish this tablet had a usb port for a junk drive. Still trying to get use it.

Reviews.Title: fabulous tablet, great pictur quality, intuitive to use makes it a home run for those new to tablets
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: But for two issues this would be an easy 5 star rating.  The control buttons are located on the front of the tablet which means that you frequently inadvertently hit one and you go back or to the home page.  This happens most when using it as an ereader or while playing games.  Once you have done this a bunvh of times you do become careful how to hold the tablet.  The power and volume controls are inbedded in the side and I eventually will remember where they are and not keep turning the tablet over and around.The second issue is that it is not compatible with the adope flash reader so you cannot watch Amazon video content.  There are numerous companies that you can get movies from but I was considering Amazon prime.Tablets now are like vhs and beta back in the old days, eventually there will be dome consistency amoung the manufacturers.The picture is fabulous, it is easy to use and the keyboard is the best of any tablet I tried.  I like the 10.1 inch size even though it is bulky to carry, the benefits far outweigh the detriment.Added note:  If you need more storage it is far easier to add a micro sd card when you can catch them deeply discounted (many were 70-80 percent off for Black Friday, etc.)  For $23.00, I added 32gb of storage.  Had I purchased the model with the additional storage it was around 100.00 more.  The trick is to find the sale on the micro card.  Staples will price match Amazon, and I always check Amazon's prices before I shop as they are usually unbeatable.

Reviews.Title: tablet border
Reviews.Author: Jess D.
Reviews.Content: Good tablet and a good size to work with but when handing it to someone else to show a picture or something the edges are a little too narrow they touch the screen and the picture goes away . Other than that it is a vary good tablet

Reviews.Title: Super Fine Dandy
Reviews.Author: Oliver C. Felton
Reviews.Content: Love the portability of it while traveling and the light weight. Great little computer. Great for what I needed and have recommended it already.

Reviews.Title: Everything excellent
Reviews.Author: Maria Pinto
Reviews.Content: Excellent job my friend. The tablet was just on time. Samsung Galaxy tab 3 is an excellent product. Thanks by all

Reviews.Title: Great tablet
Reviews.Author: Linda D. Baker
Reviews.Content: I have no other experience with tablets, but this one has great HD quality, and so far, I'm pleased with the functions that I can perform with it.

Reviews.Title: Great
Reviews.Author: philliesfan115 "big bob"
Reviews.Content: Very happy works like a charm does what it's supposed to do couldn't be happier, bought it as a surprise and every one is happy

Reviews.Title: Great Tablet
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I read all kinds of bad reviews on this table but it is pretty decent.  My first tablet besides a Kindle Fire and I love it...So much fun...  Great product and if you have a phone from Samsung you can definitely work this tablet!!  LOVE IT :) :)

Reviews.Title: Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 10.1inch Tablet...
Reviews.Author: JJHII
Reviews.Content: I purchased this for my son...This was the one that he wanted...He is thrilled with it...I works great and has a beautiful screen...No complaints and I would purchase this over the iPad anyday and I own an  iPad...

Reviews.Title: Review Of Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 10.1
Reviews.Author: TG
Reviews.Content: The Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 10.1 is much better than the Apple ipad 1-3. The wife uses all of these platforms, with the Tab 3 as a birthday present. Poor girl has no technology to play with after work.The interface is more user friendly for beginners, faster, better picture and camera quality, while just staying ahead of Apple.What would have made the Tab 3 a perfect platform? Two or more GB Ram, full 1080p screen, and two more inches of screen would have made the day for most users.Best tablet on the market at present. It's a definite buy until a better unit arrives on the market.

Reviews.Title: Might have got a refurbished instead of a brand new per my request
Reviews.Author: Mellisa M
Reviews.Content: This tablet came as if it's brand new BUT it has somebody's info, when I got to my calendar I see events that I have no clue about, its so sad I got it for a price of a brand new one coz I was avoiding refurbished stuff:(

Reviews.Title: The tablet has a known battery Issue
Reviews.Author: B. Paul "btpheritage"
Reviews.Content: I bought the tablet and it works fine, but after 3 months the battery takes 18 hours to 24 hours to charge fully.  Sending the tablet back and it was very difficult working with Samsung Support.  Very disappointed in the battery.  On the internet you will find that Samsung has a known issue with the battery, but they seem ignorant of the issue.

Reviews.Title: Tab 3
Reviews.Author: Corey blevins
Reviews.Content: I bought this refurbished, and the product itself was in immaculate condition. The only problem I've encountered so far is the touch screen. Sometimes it bounces around uncontrollably, or it becomes unresponsive. I've had to turn the device off when this problem occurs, and everything seems to go back to normal. I'm not sure if this is a common problem with the tab 3 10.1, but if it continues, then I will definitely have to return it.

Reviews.Title: love it love it love it.
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: this is my favorite android tablet. I use it daily. However I will remark that if you only use it for streaming Netflix, the battery will drain faster and faster. I bought two and tested it out by playing Netflix movies until the battery drained to 25%. I did this experiment daily, recharging it every time and at first I had a 6 hour battery life....now it is down to 4.5 hours.If you really want a great PC tablet I recommend the Dell 8 Venue Pro. It is faster but the screen resolution for Netflix sucks and Samsung has a really great resolution and color with little buffering problems if any. It all depends on how you want to use the tablet. For Kindle reading, surfing the net and buying very neat android apps, mostly free on amazon, I recommend the Samsung Galaxy Tab 3. If you are only interested in surfing the net and emails, then the Dell PC tablet is faster.Lastly if you purchase this Samsung, go and buy the Amazon Basic case with handle. It fits perfectly and has a great side pocket for all of your toys.and gadgets. I love this case. Its is made of neophane, light weight and works great.Also buy the USB adapter. It is a USB Micro-8 to USB A 4-pin. This way you can hook up a flash drive or SD card reader and double or triple your storage. I downloaded all of my movies from DVD to two large SD cards and play movies when on the plane. I highly recommend this adapter. My favorite is one that Walmart sells..."StarTech com. Model number UUSBOTGADAP. It costs around $4-5 bucks. I ended up buying 4 so I can use it for all of my tablets [Dell and Samsung]. If you order it from Walmart, they will ship to your closest store and shipping is free and you get it within days. Amazon sells their own adapters...just make sure you order a USB Micro-8 to USB A 4-pin. The good thing about StarTech is that is is very small and has no cord....but easier to lose...so buy a backup or two.  Some complaints is that the USB port is on the bottom of the tablet and you can not use a stand because the adapter is in the way. Turn over the tablet! It will still work and the adapter will be on the top, out of the way.

Reviews.Title: Great Tablet Even for Just a Dual Core
Reviews.Author: R. B. Zimmerman "pulsartech"
Reviews.Content: First off, I didnt buy mine through Amazon but I felt this would be a better place to post a review of it since a lot people look at Amazon for reviews and other info.This is just a dual core tablet but with the Intel processor, 2 cores is all you will need!  The tablet is incredibly snappy, switching between apps like a champ.  You would think that all of that processing power would come at a cost to battery life but that's not true.I had a Google Nexus 7 that I bought when they first came out.  Its a good little tablet but its a little small for reading magazines on.  The 10.1 screen of the Tab 3 is a much better form factor for reading magazines on (more legible screen).  I was also amazed at the incredible battery life that I got with the Tab 3 compared to the Nexus 7.  With the Nexus 7 I was charging the tablet almost daily.  With the Tab 3 I am able to go days if not a full week (depending on how I am using it).  With the Nexus 7 I was having a lot of issues with keeping it connected to my wireless N in the house.  It would stutter a lot while trying to watch video on.  I actually had to create a guest wireless account with it locked at wireless G speeds only for it to stay connected.  With the Tab 3 I was able to connect to the wireless N without any issues.  It even connects to the 5Ghz band without issues.  I am able to stream HBO Go and shows from my Directv Genie system.I would highly recommend this tablet to anyone looking for a good android based 10.1 inch tablet.

However, the iPad doesn't allow you to expand the storage and it doesn't have a USB port, so that I can easily transfer music and pics more quickly than over WiFi. My one complaint thus far is that it is very slow surfing compared to my Macbook Pro or even my iPhone running over the same WiFi. It's kind of frustrating, but it get's the job done. I'm taking this little baby to Europe in place of my laptop, so we'll see how it works across the pond. I think that if you're looking for something in a reasonable price range that is easily accessible and easy to learn, this is a good option. The size is also great as well. I was seriously torn between the 8" and the 10.1". The 10.1" is closer to an iPad in size. Also, it's still small enough to through into a purse/bag. It can't fit in a pocket, but if you plan to use this for more than just reading a novel, you'll appreciate the larger size-still very light.  I'm enjoying it thus far. Additionally, I'm young, but I have very poor eyesight. I appreciate that I was able to increase the font as soon as I turned it on.

This makes it completely awkward to have the charger in while you're using it - in fact, I have to unplug the power cord (and plug it back in) when I flip open my case (Moko case). Reviews.Title: Love it so far
Reviews.Author: Muhammad "Mu"
Reviews.Content: I'll update this review later as I do with most electronics because the true test of it spans a few months.First impressions after having it for a week, this is a great tablet; It may not be top of the line, but it works very well for what I need. My last tablet was an Asus Transformer Prime which I bought two and half years ago. Even today the Prime had specs to rival the majority of top tier tablets; quad core processor, plenty of ram and memory, an incredible screen, but it was so damn unstable. It would lag, freeze, WiFi was weak due to the aluminum backing, internet browsing was a chore, and eventually the keyboard became so frustrating and unusable. The camera wiring was shoddy and stopped working a year ago, and the screen finally gave out when I dropped it while it was in a case, in my bag, from a height of two feet or so. I decided I was done with ASUS tablets, and electronics in general from the less reputable companies.This Galaxy Tab 3 so far has been a dream to use. It's not really faster, and the screen is actually a lower resolution so it's a little less crisp, but I didn't need something much more powerful and I don't care if app icons look "a little fuzzy" as some people complain about. I just needed something from a reliable manufacturer that was stable and fluid. And so far I've gotten exactly that. Still a 10" screen thats very bright with excellent picture and movie quality, a little smaller, much lighter, switching apps is smooth, it doesn't lag as much, the WiFi signal capability is stronger than my Droid RAZR, and the Samsung UI feels much more polished.Overall, I'm thoroughly enjoying this tablet. I considered the Galaxy Note 10.1 because it has more memory, 1.5-2GB I believe depending on the model, as opposed to 1GB the Tab 3, but it still runs very fast. I use it for browsing, games, and all my class textbooks, PDFs, and streamed lectures. It runs everything very well. I guess if you have use for the stylus or need the ability to run dual apps side by side, maybe doing a lot of spreadsheets, note taking, and business that requires complete fluidity, maybe go for the Note so you'll never be starved for extra memory to run fast. But the Tab 3 is an excellent tablet for the Value, and I got it for about half the price I paid for my Prime when it was initially released.

Reviews.Content: Disclaimer: I've only owned this tablet a month and my overall impression of this mobile computing option is "unimpressed."The advantages of using a small, fast device should be weighed against the downside: your "imput interaction" is considerably more difficult than it is with say, a laptop and I can seldom find a comfortable way to hold the device such that I can type without accidentally covering the wifi antenna, pressing the "previous screen" button near the bottom or the "home" button (also near the bottom). I left my laptop at home on my recent vacation and regretted the decision daily.I have had a problem in charging the tablet for about 2 weeks. It takes multiple connection attempts to finally see the unit taking a charge via the wall socket adapter (I have not had the problem when charging via the USB conected to my laptop). Once the charge indicator shows the battery is being charged, it usually takes about 10-15 minutes before the charging stops leaving the unit in a perpetually-undercharged condition. Multiple searches on Google haven't helped me find a solution, so it's possible this is a rare condition. I strongly suspect it's software related, although I have found other charging-related issues with the Tab 3 on the internet that were related to problems with the battery connections.

Reviews.Title: Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 (10.1-Inch, Gold-Brown)
Reviews.Author: BlacklightHalo
Reviews.Content: Overall, this tablet is a big hit with me. I bought it after a two-year run with a Blackberry Playbook 7" Tablet, and for the most part this is a much better experience. There are a lot of things which could (and should) be easily possible with tablets these days which I'm appalled to see that many of them don't do (reading common file formats, etc.) This tablet does most of those things as if it that were just "how it's done," which is exactly what it should do.What I like:This tablet comes with removable storage capacity. Whereas more and more companies these days are realizing that people will buy more devices faster if they have to upgrade to the next-largest hard-drive every time they run out of space, it's refreshing to see a MicroSD card slot in a tablet. This is one of those things that, when a company doesn't do it, I think "really? How can you possibly imagine you'll get away with that?" Once again, though, here this is not an issue. It's also much more universally compatible than a lot of its competitors. For instance, I can pair my Bluetooth Speaker with it effortlessly, despite the fact that it was made by Skosche and not Samsung. It's agreeable and not finicky.Then there's the capabilities it gives you with photos. For me, the ability to crop and otherwise edit my photos in the same device that took them is a big deal, and this tablet offers many apps each with various useful options in how to do this. You can also disable location-based services. As a privacy-conscious person, I definitely approve of this, especially when most apps demand permission to view your location, even when they have no need of that information to perform their function. "GPS" is one of the options in the top-menu that you can shut-off completely with a single touch.Then there's the multiple desktops feature. This is one of the reasons I so love Linux OS. I'd like to be able to give each desktop a different wallpaper, but maybe this will be in a future update. Another thing I enjoy is the ability to use the file-browser of my computer to access and change the contents of the tablet's hard drive. I can just drag-and-drop files into folders, which is far and away better than a tablet which requires you to download its proprietary "desktop manager" or other corporate software to manage its contents and then be SOL when said software inexplicably malfunctions (I'm looking at you, Apple and RIM!)Also, speaking of the lack of corporate meddling, this tablet is a mostly DRM-free-zone. While unfortunately there's copy-protection on a lot of the Play Store media content (like eBooks,) if you tend to get your media from others sources (like downloading music from Amazon or ripping movies from DVDs you own) then you'll find yourself perfectly able to enjoy your own legal right to copy your own files across your own devices on your own terms, and access them on your own terms as well. This NEEDS to become a socio-economic norm, and I applaud any company who already does things this way.What I think could be better:The port at the bottom of this device for charging and syncing is TINY. Micro USB is a TERRIBLE choice for something that has to be plugged in and left to charge or sync as often as a tablet, because it really can't take much of a bump without being damaged and becoming unusable. Maybe they think this is somehow a more efficient use of space, or maybe this is more of that "make it suck so people will have to pay for repairs and replacements more frequently" phenomena I mentioned, but I would be stoked if they'd just put a regular-sized USB port on it, like they have on the other end of the cable. Smaller is NOT always better, and there's plenty of space on the bottom of this tablet for a standard USB port.Also, while this tablet's onscreen appearance is appealingly customizable, you can't change a few things that I'd really like to change. For instance, the drop-down menu that gives access to your WiFi, Bluetooth, GPS, etc options is a really abrasive white-with-black-and-blue-font. The same is true of the options menu. This wouldn't be such a bone-of-contention with me if I could invert or even customize the color scheme, but apparently no one thought of this in designing Jelly-Bean. Unfortunately those colors are really harsh on my eyes, especially if I have to use the tablet at night (and I take night classes, so... yeah.) The least they could do here is create a "night mode" that inverts the colors to reduce eye-strain. I'd like to see this as an OS update in the near future.Also, this tablet will not communicate with a computer running Linux OS no matter what mode I set it to use. I guess most people don't (yet) use Linux, so this is likely not a problem for you. But considering that Android is *based* on Linux and has many of the features that Linux users enjoy, this should not be happening. I even have a smaller Android tablet (Archos 43) which does not have this problem. But sadly in the case of the Galaxy 3, "Droid doesn't."Overall, this tablet is a huge improvement in my life and I'm very thankful to have it, despite its aforementioned shortcomings. It's not absolutely perfect by my standards, but it's at least several steps in the correct direction and makes the technological and business aspects of my life overall much easier. I would recommend this tablet.

Reviews.Title: Awesome Samsung Tablet with Android OS
Reviews.Author: Rhonda Peters "cooking healthy"
Reviews.Content: I absolutely love, love, love my Galaxy Tab 3 10.1 Tablet!  It was this tablet that actually made me put down my iPad, which I never thought I could do!  The fact that many of the apps that I used frequently on my iPad where also available with the same or similar experience, made it easy for me to convert!!!  I also loved the fact that many of the book in the Play Store are less expensive!  Okay let's talk features!  This tablet is thin and light compared to my iPad 3, which seems so heavy now.  One of the best tech feature is the option to use a micro SD card slot for extra storage, and of course USB support!  This also means that the cables are much less expensive and I don't have to buy "special attachments" for every little thing that would cost me about $40!In addition, I love the fact that I can work on Word docs, PowerPoint Slides and excel spreadsheets and then save them to the hard drive or upload them to the Cloud (via Drive).  This is a great feature because I am always working on various documents while on the go!  I am a huge Google user so the setup is very easy and my experience is the same as if I were on a laptop.  I love the Smart Eyes features where the tablet goes to sleep when it can't detect your eyes looking at the screen.  I am still exploring new features everyday.  It took me a long time to figure out how to close the apps running in the background! LOL!Lastly, if you're like me, you still may need a keyboard to really take advantage of this tablet because the SWYPE method can only go so far during dictation!  I purchased the Logitech Bluetooth Keyboard for this tablet and it's like a mini laptop!  The downside to that keyboard that I have learned is that is drains the battery very quickly!  There are various keyboards that you can get to support this tablet, just explore and find the one you like the best!I have other #Inteltablets, but this Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 is one of my Top 3 picks! #IntelFan

Reviews.Title: Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 vs Nexus 10 vs ASUS Transformer T100TA
Reviews.Author: drifter yank
Reviews.Content: Over a period of several weeks I tried out the following.  (I will post this same review in Amazon under each device.)1. ASUS Transformer T100 hybrid tablet/notebook  2. Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 10.1 Tablet 3. Google Nexus 10 tabletI also looked at an iPad Air.  They are way overpriced.  And I still have a grudge against Apple for the 2012 hard drive recall they had on our 27" iMac.  It was a total disaster.  We didn't lose any data but it took weeks and endless phone calls to get it running right again.After spending a day getting used to Windows 8, I thought the ASUS might be the one I was going to keep.  I actually only tried it for two days.  Early on day three I shut it down only to have it remain on the "Shutting Down" screen for an extended time period.  So I powered it off.  Apparently, my bad.  Subsequently it would not reboot into Windows, reset or repair even after talking with ASUS Tech Support.  They asked me to return it to them for repair.  I declined and returned it to WallyI liked the ASUS.  It was attractive but a fingerprint magnet both front and back. And it was more difficult to use than Android.  The two issues that bothered me most were the lack of a Swype app and the complications of dictation.  The best Swype-type app in the Windows Store is TouchPal.  It ain't that good.  First of all the virtual keyboard is large. Your finger has to cover a lot of real estate to enter characters.  Also, the word prediction accuracy sucks. Windows-supported dictation was not that accurate, so I had to go into Google to dictate.  This was not nearly as handy as being in a Google operating system to begin with.  I use Swype and dictation a lot.The mentioned issues relate to Windows 8 not the physical unit.  I liked the ASUS unit enough that I discovered they make several similar models running Android.  After checking these out I found they were either running old versions of Android or cost a couple of hundred dollars more than the two Samsung models mentioned here.  So, that ended that.It was hard to choose between the Nexus and the Galaxy,  Both are made by Samsung.  I waited several weeks to see if a new Nexus 10 was coming out but to no avail.As far as looks go, the Galaxy is very thin and attractive.  In my opinion it is as nice looking as an iPad even though it has more plastic.  I had the white one so fingerprints were not that visible.  The Galaxy gets compliments for its narrow bezels.  However these are really a functional negative. They cause you to touch and activate stuff on the screen accidentally quite often.  Makes me suspect the iPad has the same problem.  There are a lot of complaints about the large area of sensitivity for the three built-in keys at the bottom of the Galaxy.  However I thought this was minor compared to the narrow side bezels.  (You can probably negate the side bezel problem by putting the unit in a folio case. It could give you more to hang onto.) The speakers are on the top of the sides and are easy to cover up when holding the unit.Though made by Samsung, because Google's name is on it the Nexus is first in line for Android updates. It has already downloaded the latest Android version, KitKat.  It will also be the first to get future updates since there is no manufacturer software OS overlay to wait for.  It is pure Android--no bloatware.  In terms of specs, the Nexus blows the other two units away.  The broad bezels may not be as attractive but they give you something to hang onto without accidental screen touches.  The Nexus' rubber-like coating on the back is better for grip and not a fingerprint magnet.  Less bling but more practical. The Nexus' speakers are on the on the front, the best place.Even though I did not keep the Galaxy and its specs are much less impressive than the Nexus, I found it perfectly satisfactory for my needs.  I do mainly Web browsing, Email, some text and spreadsheet documents and a few non-graphic intensive games. I bought all of these units from local big box stores.  The Nexus 10 was $400 and the two Samsung units were only about $30 less.After considerable researching of portable Bluetooth keyboards, I ordered and just received a Kensington KeyFolio Pro 2 Universal Case and Keyboard.  I bought this from Amazon and will review it when I have had it for awhile.  So far this looks like a terrific and attractive accessory  I will probably keep the Nexus in the protective case without the keyboard most of the time.  I will use the keyboard when I do a lot of data entry.

We just got fed up and ended up connecting the laptop. Also, the adapter plug we bought from Radio Shack for the HDMI cable to the TV did not connect very well and we had to fiddle with it until we got a secure connection. That may have been the fault of the Radio Shack equipment however.  I also wish it had a flash.On top of this I am disappointed with its picture taking ability. I hit the "take a picture" icon and sometimes it does it right away, and other times it seems to be focusing in and out, in and out, and it takes about ten tries before it will actually take the picture. REALLY INFURIATING!. I don't know if I'm doing something wrong, but surely it shouldn't be that "iffy". I'll be phoning Samsung about it when I get back home.The most annoying thing about it is that the bezel around the bottom "back" and "menu" icons is way, way too sensitive (as noted by a CNET reviewer). If you grip the frame anywhere on the bottom it activates one or the other.  If it's not in a case of some kind you have to juggle it when in Portrait mode.  I think it must have been designed to be used in a case.Another thing I don't like is that it comes preloaded with a lot of apps that i don't need or want and I can't seem to get rid of them. You can uninstall apps you got from Google Play but not the preloaded Samsung apps, to the best of my knowledge. They take up valuable memory.One thing I anticipated using it for, and it was successful in doing, was playing back TV shows and movies downloaded on the laptop then transferred to the mini SD card using a mini card adapter. We bought an adapter for our headphones at Radio Shack and were able to plug two sets in at once so we could both watch while on the bus for 4 hours in Mexico. The Tab 3 worked well for that although I would have liked a little more volume. I will take a previous reviewers advice re the Marley buds.  Good picture though. It seemed to have good battery life too which worked in our favour. It does charge quite quickly and holds it for quite some time.I also find the layout for Hotmail confusing. Why can't it just give me the same layout I get on the laptop?All in all, it was a lot of money for not many uses.

Reviews.Title: Android still needs work
Reviews.Author: Dyre Logan
Reviews.Content: I used to be an Android user back in the day when the phones were just coming out and it was new and not Blackberry or iOS which people had mixed reviews on. I have been an iOS user for many years now since no one was able to come out with a decent MP3 player except Apple. So, that being said, I do like Android and but I am prepared for being called Apple "fanboy" or any other names because I choose iOS over Android all because of functionality but I will be making iOS comparisons throughout the review.I bought this very light, very sleek tablet for my mother who is in desperate need of an upgrade from her extremely tiny Verizon netbook obviously built for Hobbits. I had it ship to me so that I could set it up for her and so that I could learn about it before handing it over and explaining everything to her. I have not used Android in a while and I explained to her that Samsung is a great company that comes out with great phones such as Galaxy S3 and S4, although I have never used these phones but have seen them in use.The first thing that I did when I was taken to the home screen was go right to the settings to change a few things as this was for my mother and I wanted to make it as easy and painless as possible as Android is a little more difficult than iOS, especially when it comes to app deletion which is easier on iOS  as all you have to do is hold the app down, click the red circle and voila! gone. not so much with Android. you have to go to settings, then to apps then click delete app. a little more to do, but not really that bad. The next thing I did was check out the apps and the functionality of the device. That's when I shook my head.Jelly Bean 4.2.2. Still very VERY leggy and choppy and still VERY delayed since when I first used Android back when it was in its infancy. Apps would take 3-5 seconds to open up. The screen is not as fluid as iOS as it takes several swipes to get it moving. It's as if you had multiple apps and programs and movies playing using up all the resources. Not so when it comes to me, as I always close all the apps after I use them and don't plan on using them again for a while.The apps are not clear and crisp, which I understand could be the developers not updating their apps, but when reading text or viewing apps and album covers you see blurry or just plain unreadable text and images of apps you wish to purchase, it makes one lose faith in Samsung who is supposed to be a great innovator of sharp images. Their TV's are phenomenal, but alas, their tablet falls way short when it comes to sharpness and functionality.I love playing with this tablet, but after using an iPad since its inception several years ago, even when the iPad 1 was super slow and heavy, I find Samsung's version a little tiresome as I have already seen all of its functionality in the iPad. I understand that Google and Apple have been butting heads and stealing from each other since they both came out with their mobile technology but when you see cookie cutter copycats of functions and features in other tablets you tend to get a little bored. But, you have to go with what works and what is popular.I love the live wallpapers on Android, but yes, it's a resource hog. I'm sure there are other functions I have to limit or turn off in order to get the 7-10 hour usage, but I am realistic. What are those features on there for if they want you to turn them off to get the full functionality out of it? Same goes for the iPad and iPhone and other brands. They give you features then tell you not to use them if you want the battery to give you many hours of usage. With the Galaxy Tab 3, however, when the battery tells you it's now at 93% after about 15 minutes and you have 3 and a half hours left of usage, there is something wrong. Even my nearly year old iPad 3 gives me more usage than a brand new Galaxy.I know this review sounds like I am bashing Android and praising iOS and downing Samsung and lifting up Apple, but I still think that this tablet has promise and I know it just came out and I am sure it can get better, but I have to say that a 400 dollar price tag is a bit too much. This tablet, in my opinion, is maybe worth about 300-325 dollars if that. Because it is slow, because of its minimal features. I feel the same way about the iPad. I have the 64gb version and I feel that 700 is way too much for this tablet too. I think it is worth maybe 400-450 if that. But, you are paying for the name, of course, so I understand that. If the Galaxy was made by Asus I would probably pay 299 for what it does.Another thing I didn't care for about the Galaxy, and I know this is an issue with Skype  is the video feature doesn't work. I can see myself but the other person cannot see me, even though I began a video call. I researched it and found others are having the same issues.That being said, I will play with the tablet a little longer and I am optimistic as I have only had it for a day. But if I was given the chance, and money, even though Apple is way too high priced for what you get, I would not buy this tablet again and I would buy my mother an iPad. For the sake of its ease of use, functionality, and hardly any delay in its applications or features. Hopefully Samsung will come out with an OS that works fluidly like iOS and some firmware to fix some other things.

Reviews.Title: Totally Worthless Device
Reviews.Author: W. Kincy "Anyone"
Reviews.Content: bought a Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 10.1 inch tablet a couple of days ago.  I was adding it to a Lenovo W520 Thinkpad, X220 Thinkpad, Gen 1 iPad, home built desktop, and an iPhone 5.  I have been with the iPhone for 12 months coming from an Android HTC Sensation 4G that I had for 3 years, so am not totally unfamiliar with the Google OS for android devices.I also should preface this with the fact that I still am very actively at work and mostly use these devices for profitable work product.  My main work effort is keeping in contact with and being available to about 500 clients for advice when they need and want it, which results in needing to accurately keep up with 800 or so contacts.  I only say this so you understand that my primary need for the device was as a larger iPhone clone to keep in contact and read email and get client info right away when I need it and to replace my aging iPad Gen 1.My main source of client data and email is my Outlook 2010 although I also have a Hotmail account, GMail account, Yahoo account, and an Exchange account.  The proliferation of calendars, and contacts folders across multiple accounts and multiple devices is a nightmare and I have yet to find any cloud device that doesn't cause more problems in that management task than it solves.Unfortunately I must add the Galaxy Tab 3 to that list of failed devices.  The iPad Gen 1 although now ancient and the iPhone will with some trouble sync using iTunes with Microsoft Outlook. This is the main folder I use for my important contact data.Although it has been said by Google that you can use Google as an interface between your Microsoft and your Apple devices for contact management it is simply not true.  After nearly 12 concentrated hours of cleaning up and synching my multiple devices in to a clean concise Outlook.pst and Outlook.csv file, I was totally unable to get that file into the Samsung tablet although I had no problem importing it into Google as a comma delimited file.  I tried to import the Google contacts into the Samsung Tablet and although that works on any of the PCs or the Desktop through Google, I was unable to get the Google accounts showing on the Samsung tablet to show any of the 800 contacts at all.  Yet GMail would come onto the Tablet as would my other email.  It is important to also note that fact that the amount of email I get completely overwhelmed the Tablets email applications ability to show and organize it.I than tried Kies to download the Contacts, Calendar and Tasks.  Absolutely no go.  Given the number of accounts I have I need to pick the specific Main Outlook PST file to sync over to the Samsung with Kies.  Once you check the box for Selected Outlook folders, Kies will freeze up and not show the choices of folder to select for the download.  Several times after walking away from the tablet for over 30 minutes it would finally show the selection of the appropriate folder, but than would download about 4 iterations of each of the 800 contacts and 3200 contacts in a single contacts folder with only 800 discrete files is not what I would call successfulI would think this Samsung device is wonderful for folks that are not looking to spend Apple iPad money and want to mainly use the tablet for music, photos, and games and a small set of contacts and a few emails a day, but it certainly is not for someone that has a lot of data and emails they need to keep close track of.It has been reset and it going back to the store.WK

Reviews.Content: Its alright to be my first tablet just really upset that samsung doesnt carry flash player on  the play store you need to download it from the internet not fair paying so much and you cant see nothing . And sometimes the browser gets slow..but to video chat , and record and etc its pretty good . If I had another choice I would've brought another tablet not this one .

Reviews.Title: Not Properly Working No Communication From Seller
Reviews.Author: Jessica Sparkman
Reviews.Content: Turned on the tablet after it arrived in a paper envelope from the post office. There was a large black circle on the screen. That is not useable because the whole point of a tablet is to use the entire screen. I have contacted the seller and have not heard back from them. I did exactly as their return policy stated by emailing them with my order code. Nothing. I have now processed my claim with Amazon. Do not buy. Save your money if you can.

Reviews.Title: Expensive HDMI connection
Reviews.Author: Denise Henry
Reviews.Content: The tablet itself is great, but I had hoped to get an inexpensive, easy way to hook up the tablet to the HDMI cord.  Not happening....

Reviews.Content: First of all I received my item late, then when I got it the sim card slot is broke now I got to send it back now ima b without the tab and money for about another month probably

Reviews.Title: hate it
Reviews.Author: Karen L. Thompson
Reviews.Content: Totally disgusted!Purchased a movie on Media Hub for the grandkids and we cant view it without the "title box" popping up and the only option is to click "play"again. I called customer support 5 times and each time was given a different set of instructions to solve the problem and nothing works! When grandma is trying to cook and every 2 minutes the kids yell that the movie stopped again, it gets very annoying! I deselected the blocking mode, I disabled the timer to shut down, I clear the cache in media hub application and something else I was instructed to do and yet the darn movie still will not play in it's entirety.The other annoying feature is not being able to view the contents of the tablet on a larger device such as a tv or larger computer without purchasing an HDMI cable. Nor can we save the purchased movies to the storage card I purchased separetly. This device will be returned!

Reviews.Title: TABLET RATING
